p: Traditional medicines based on such medicinal plants are often preferred over modern therapies due to low costs, few adverse effects, bioavailability, and efficacy [ 23, 24, 25, 26]. Among different antimicrobial agents, plant extracts have attracted significant attention in antibacterial studies [ 27, 28, 29]. Capsaicin (8-Methyl- N-vanillyl-6-nonenamide), the active component of cayenne pepper has been grown as a food and for medicinal purposes since ancient times. Multiple pharmacological and physiological properties, such as anti-microbial and anti-virulence activities, are associated with capsaicin and are the subject of ongoing research activities [ 30, 31, 32]. The efficacy of active compounds in medicinal plants can be improved by either nanosizing or incorporating them into nanostructures [ 33, 34].
